comments.commentBody: FB, I wonder about you, complaining about a clue when you know Martin is preoccupied.  Not sure your change is any better. Perhaps it should be Tristan's love, which it has been twice before, but IMNSHO Camelot refers to more than just a geographical site. It's folklore and in that sense the clue is acceptable. If JFK can be referred to as Camelot, so can ISEULT.

While much of what you describe is accurate, just demanding Greece get competent is not going to happen.  The Germans and other creditors have to recognize that growth is essential for the only positive outcome possible, regardless of morality, fault, or guilt.  What Krugman is saying is that there is plenty of history to suggest that Europe will go South in a bad way if this situation blows up.  That will affect security, peace, and prosperity globally.  But how to force Greece to improve it's public sector performance.  It is interesting that the blame game is paramount in human discourse, while the technocratic details of how Greece should be guided along a reform course do not get much attention.  Many of the Greek ills are described here, but there needs to be recognition in the country too.  Now we are headed towards an economic conflict where Germany will again spearhead actions that could potentially seriously damage Europe.

"Carthaginian peace" was imposed on fascist Germany in 1945. Sorry for the delay.
Another 70 million dead later...
The case of Greece is entirely different. The culprits (the bankers) have left the ship long ago...
I don't see why Greece defaulting forces Greece out of its own currency (the Euro). Please explain.
In any case that's clearly a pressure tactic. Posturing.

Or that he should have addressed it to Obama, because that's what op ed writers from other countries who are in the government have traditionally done....

No, I'm sorry, there's no way to make that analogy work. It's one of the most bizarre ideas I've ever read in my life.

Totally agree about "Dear Committee Members" - in fact, I gave a copy to each member of my faculty team. I also agree about stopping books that award-givers seem to think I would like. I couldn't finish Americanah. Sad, but true.

I thought "Being Mortal" was honest, insightful, and compelling - but then I'm a family physician so the subject is my front line.
I think it's wonderful. It's just taking me a while to digest each small bit.

Even while all you say is correct, the desperately-needed investment and the essential clean-up of the Greek public sector are a chicken and egg dilemma.  Which can possibly come first?  The creditors have provided funds, but at terms that slowly kill Greece and create massive suffering, which is ultimately an unwise policy against your debtors.  It is so bad that we are facing loss of security, peace, prosperity, and stability in Europe.  The Greeks are thinking that default can't be much worse, but have yet to modernize their public sector.  That is why this conflict is coming to a head on Feb. 27.

Too much is being made of the psychiatrist's use of the mood scale with a target mood being 100%. If instead, the scale was used similarly to a pain scale where the patient states a number from 0-10, where 0 is no pain and 10 the worst pain, there would be less controversy. A pain level of 3 (say) may be expressed by the patient as an acceptable level of pain.
If the mood scale was turned upside down and an acceptable point on the scale of mood was determined by the patient, then targeting that point as a goal for treatment would not seem as impossible. If 0 were no anxiety/depression and 100 the worst anxiety/depression, then 20% may be expressed as an acceptable target. The idea is not aiming for no mood disturbance but an acceptable level of dysphoria.

This is a great idea for post or series of posts for this blog! I know our neighbor kept quiet when her daughter dated an older boy because she figured it would be over soon and voicing her opinions would just prolong it. Well, her daughter ended up dating for a long time, marrying the guy, they stayed married for about a year, then had a nasty break up. I know she wishes she spoke up at the early stages, but I don't know that it would have changed anything. I would love to hear from seasoned parents whose kids have successfully navigated their dating life and have survived to adulthood.
It would sure have to be after the fact! No teenager would put up with as-it-happens on that one. But it is a good idea. I'll see what we can do.

Being switched at birth would have mattered to your children though.  They know their mother before they're born - her voice, heartbeat, rhythms - and as so as they're born, they know her scent and her touch.  Despite what we're told as adoptees, you can't simply replace one mother for another without there being a HUGE impact on infants.

I'm also an adoptee with 2 biological children. I found it was cool to finally see a biological relative, but it wasn't quite as profound a feeling as I expected. After having the baby for a day or two, it occurred to me that I wouldn't have loved him less if it turned out he was switched at birth and not an actual biological relative.

I think nature does have an impact in our lives, but it isn't the total picture.

Wish I knew the trick. My kid finally learned, but was pretty old. I think he still slips his sneakers on and off when changing for gym class rather than tying or untying. The bunny thing didn't work for me. Kid said his teacher used a different method using a snake, but he couldn't explain it to me.

Great post, and with three children in their twenties, you've given me a lot to think about. It works in reverse also....the "golden child" who was bound to be a Nobel Prize winner ends up maybe "not so much."  We have to work hard to see our children for who they are at this moment, not in the past and not in the future, and celebrate them for who they are - right now.
I'm another white adoptive mother of a Korean-born daughter just writing to thank you for this post. And that is such a wonderful and adorable photo!
What? I got no sense of resentment whatsoever out of this article.

I don't understand your suggestion that Julia is resentful. She was honest about what growing up adopted was like for her. That isn't resentment. t's honesty.
This is known as adoptee-on-adoptee backlash. Sadly not uncommon in the adoption world.

Love this - and especially all the suggestions in the comments, too. I've been busily toggling between reading these and adding to my (far too lengthy to ever be accomplished) Goodreads list.

One note: Amnesia didn't win the Booker Prize, though the author has won it twice previously, for other books. I've liked several of their recent nominees and winners, including We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves, To Rise Again at a Decent Hour, The Lowland, and We Need New Names. Some years seem to be "misses" for me, but their lists often lead me to discover a treasure I wouldn't have otherwise found.
That's good to know, AJ. Thanks.

Let's say hypothetically that this were a piece about the writer's reaction to her parents' divorce, or a loved one's death, or a serious illness diagnosis -- any painful or difficult situation. Would you feel compelled (or for that matter, even justified) to comment about other people you know who responded differently than the writer?  Even if they were "old friends" you'd "known for decades," would you think it appropriate or useful to comment, Huh, that's funny, I know two people who did not react as you did.  I doubt it. This is the kind of dismissive pushback that adoptees are constantly subjected to, and the underlying message is clear: there is no real trauma involved in adoption that can't be gotten over, the biological loss is not important, a loving adoptive family can make up for any pain, and on and on.  Your use of the extremely disrespectful term "Angry Adoptee" is an attempt to dismiss and deny the actual lived experiences of this writer and many adoptees, an attempt to de-legitimize their experiences and silence their voices.  You are certainly entitled to share your honest reaction, and yes you're well within the NYT blog comment rules, but that does not mean your comment is not deeply dismissive and hurtful to many adoptees.

My concern about teen dating is the often heartbreaking break-up.  Articles (even here in MotherLode) have led me to believe that it's better that they have these first romances in high school while they are at home and you can be available for advice and comfort.  If their first romance is at college, it's more difficult to to support them through it.

Thank you so much for writing this.  I teach at a community college and you are right-- the stakes are higher than anywhere else.  Before I started working here, I did not think much of community college.  I couldn't have been more wrong.  My colleagues are extremely talented, innovative, and dedicated teachers, researchers, and writers.  My students are delightful, respectful, insightful, vulnerable, underprepared, and hopeful.  Community colleges deserve more respect, not to mention more funding!

It really isn't a good idea to donate eggs. The health risks for the donor are immense and underplayed by the agencies who just want the eggs at any cost. For someone growing up as a result of egg donation there are all the problems of being adopted plus the health risks that go with not being able to trace where you came from. Egg donation is generally poor women providing eggs to rich women.

Thank you Shirley for explaining your reality as opposed to the system that wants the 'world' to think it is a wonderful thing for all-and that we all live happily ever after. Most of us do not, nor do many find siblings or relatives after five decades. The best of your narrative was that you were fortunate to have a surrogate family who was 'wonderful'- I smiled to read that.

I am also happy to know that you have connected with your siblings. I hoe that it is a reunion in progress and that you have contentment in seeing some of you in them.

Just this summer I discovered where my brother from whom I had been separated since 1947-1948 was.... in a grave. My younger sister was not even a year old when we were separated and as the adoption information is sealed and she has no memory, we will never be reunited.

May your life be better now than what it may have been in the past. Remember that even strangers wish you well if only because we share similar experiences -those that non-adoptees never can.

Thank you for being open to hearing our perspectives.  The reason you don't hear from us often is because it isn't safe to speak the truth about it.  If we, as adults adoptees, express anything but positive feelings, we are chastised as being "bitter" on not "grateful." Personally, I have tried to gently share my own story and have been rebuffed.  As an infant, I cried inconsolably for two weeks without my mother coming back.  As a child, I begged to know who my first parents were.  It was like oxygen for me. I NEEDED them and I was treated like an ungrateful brat for wanting anyone but my adoptive parents. I wanted to die.  As a teenager, I cried out through dangerous behaviors (eating disorder, drinking, reckless driving, promiscuity) for someone to recognize the pain inside that had always been there but I couldn't put words to it.  Despite all the ways I cried out, at no time did anyone suggest to me that I was grieving the loss of my first mother.  The notion that my adoptive parents were somehow better and I that I would naturally be grateful to have this "better" life was so pervasive, that nobody considered that separating me from my mother would cause trauma.  Now, as a mother and grandmother, I've felt compelled to shed light on what seems like an obvious observation.  Babies want their mothers!  However, I quickly learned that people are not open to hearing anything negative about adoption.  Once again, despite crying out for no one will hear the truth.

Not a kind word for the parents who adopted you and cared for you?  Adoption is a wonderful thing but for some reason we do not hear enough of the good stories, only the stories like yours.  Sad as this reflects a limited view and gives the wrong impression.

A mix of joy and sorrow on so many levels.

The adoptee's sorrow of losing the birth parents and sometimes knowledge of his/her origin, and hopefully the adoptee's joy of having a good family, when staying with the original family was not an option.

The adoptive parents' frequently have suffered through the losses of pregnancies and stillborn children and sometimes "just" through years of infertility and treatment and then years of waiting for the adoption.

The birth parents' loss of a child, and hopefully some small measure of joy or at least content in most cases knowing the child is being raised by loving adoptive parents.

There are lots of losses and sorrows and also many joys in adoption. I am not going to try to measure them against each other. I just hope that this continued openness and acknowledgement of all the different experiences can help us all do better.

Congratulations to Juli! I can imagine (but not know) it must feel like a little miracle to have a baby biologically related to you. I hope and fully expect that your (adoptive) parents will love her, as they love you, unconditionally.

Thank you for acknowledging that every adoption is a mix of joy and sorrow, one couple's gain, a birth mother's loss. We cannot begin to talk about adoption if we don't first affirm this. God bless you and your new daughter.

Wlukas, I know what you mean, and I agree deeply about the importance of ancestors. My grandmother lost her mother to tuberculosis when she was 18 months old--or really, when she was 8 or 9 months old, since they lived in the Panama Canal Zone and as soon as it became clear that she had TB, she was forcibly evacuated to a sanitarium in New York, where nearly a year later she died. Forced, in other words, to get on a boat and sail away from her husband (the love of her life) and their seven children.

My mom has described Grandma as "a motherless child" and said that that was key to who she was--like your mom, "a fierce mother and grandmother."
